taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Adults occur in sluggish or standing water in canals, lakes, and swamps (Ref.  12693).  Inhabit waters with submerged aquatic vegetation (Ref. 12693).  Usually found only in deep pools in rivers and occasionally in lakes.  They enter flooded forest (Ref. 9497).  Carnivorous and subsist on fish, frogs, snakes, insects, earthworms and tadpoles (Ref. 1479).  There are reports of this species taking water birds, snakes, and rodents.  Males are territorial.  May bite when caught (Elliot Bligh, pers. comm., 2001).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Asia:  India to China, south to Thailand and Cambodia (Ref. 12693) and Pakistan (Ref. 4833).
dataObjects.references: Rainboth, W.J. 1996 Fishes of the Cambodian Mekong. FAO Species Identification Field Guide for Fishery Purposes. FAO, Rome, 265 p. (Ref. 12693)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Southern and southeastern Asia: Pakistan to southern China, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam; introduced elsewhere, including southern Florida.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 183 cm TL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 6351)); max. published weight: 30.0 kg (Ref. 4833)
references: Talwar, P.K. and A.G. Jhingran 1991 Inland fishes of India and adjacent countries. Volume 2. A.A. Balkema, Rotterdam. (Ref. 4833)
Shrestha, T.K. 1990 Resource ecology of the Himalayan waters. Curriculum Development Centre, Tribhuvan University, Kathmandu, Nepal. 645 p. (Ref. 6351)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Migration
dataObjects.description: Potamodromous. Migrating within streams, migratory in rivers, e.g. Saliminus, Moxostoma, Labeo.  Migrations should be cyclical and predictable and cover more than 100 km.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Anchistrocephalus Disease. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Allogomtiorema Infestation. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: Builds floating nest of weeds and leaves where the orange-yellow eggs are deposited. Eggs hatch in 36 to 48 hours and fry remain in the nest for about 10 days after hatching. Parents guards the fry for about a month.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObjects.title: Importance
dataObjects.description: fisheries: commercial; aquaculture: commercial; gamefish: yes; aquarium: public aquariums

dataObjects.title: File:Channa marulius.jpg
dataObjects.description: English: Bullseye snakehead (Channa marulius), adult protecting young.  French: Channa marulius, adulte protégeant ses petits.

dataObjects.title: File:Channa aurolineatus(marulius) 2338.jpg
dataObjects.description: A cobra snakehead fish (Thai: ปลาช่อนงูเห่า) at the 20th Pramong Nomklao fish show event at the Future Park Rangsit, Thailand, in July 2008. The specimen was labelled as Channa aurolineatus by the event organizers, but some sources would have called it a Channa marulius instead as they did not consider C. aurolineatus a separate species. Picture taken by myself.

dataObjects.title: File:Channa marulius (Mekong) 2347.jpg
dataObjects.description: English: 1=A "Mekong River" cobra snakehead fish (Thai: ปลาช่อนงูเห่าแม่น้ำโขง) or Channa marulius at the 20th Pramong Nomklao fish show event at the Future Park Rangsit, Thailand, in July 2008. Picture taken by myself.
